instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message:
Strange issue for me. Board boots and runs well occassionally from charger only. Always runs on battery.

when not starting from charger, there is less than .5V coming in. Changed dcin port multiple different ones as that seemed the obvious likely issue. Checked resistance in lines from DCIn. Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> same symptoms. Not sure what is causing the intermittent issue. UsuallyIf I leave on the charger long enough the voltage will slowly build and the board wil turn on. Once on it stays on. Something inconsistently allowing charger to send voltage. No intermittent shorts on main rails that I can detect.
I am testing with known working 85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message:
"when not starting from charger, there is less than .5V coming in"
Do you mean F6905?
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR>, just in case.
Test with fake charger, or lab PSU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message:
Testing with lab supply I get pp3v42 instantly but no start. I haven't done that before so I'm not sure if board will actually start without adapter sense. 

If when I plug OEM charger in and montor voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, if board hasn't started usually I can watch the voltage there actually dropping until it gets to about 230mV and then it will start going back up and jump to 3.48V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message:
Use Magsafe cable from a dead charger to connect lab PSU!!!
This board requires 85W model, to start without battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message:
Ok. Yes I was testing with known working 85W charger.

With MagSafe connected to PSU, board starts immediately every time the PSU is turned on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message:
Did you use new <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>?
Post exact ohm value for <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86, measured onboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start/boot
threads.message: Turned out to be <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>. Thought I had tried replacing that already so I wasted a bunch of time running jumper wires from teh other sde of the board to ensure it wasn't a bad trace along ppDCIN. Anyway all is well and thanks for the help!
